description: From Middle English reviven, revyven, from Old French revivre and  Latin revīvō, from re- + vīvō (“live”, verb).

verbs.description: revive (third-person singular simple present revives, present participle reviving, simple past and past participle revived)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To return to life; to become reanimated or reinvigorated.
(transitive) To return to life; to cause to recover life or strength; to cause to live anew, or to prevent from dying.
examples: The dying puppy was revived by a soft hand.
Her grandmother refused to be revived if she lost consciousness.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To recover from a state of oblivion, obscurity, neglect, or depression.
examples: Classical learning revived in the fifteenth century.
The Manx language has been revived after dying out and is now taught in some schools on the Isle of Man.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To restore, or bring again to life; to reanimate; to make lively again.
examples: This new paint job should revive the surgery waiting room.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To raise from coma, languor, depression, or discouragement; to bring into action after a suspension.
(transitive) To renew in the mind or memory; to bring to recollection; to recall attention to; to reawaken.
examples: The Harry Potter films revived the world's interest in wizardry

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To recover its natural or metallic state (e.g. a metal)
(transitive) To restore or reduce to its natural or metallic state
examples: to revive a metal after calcination
